docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Laws Limit Colleges' Options When a Student Is Mentally Ill'' (front page, April 19):

headline.main: When a Student Is Mentally Ill

docs.abstract: Four letters respond to massacre at Virginia Polytechnic Institute; Dr Ronald Pies says students who are discharged from psychiatric hospital should be required to continue mental health treatment; Dr William S Appleton says that college students should be required to sign privacy waiver covering serious mental illness; Robert Fine agrees with Bob Herbert April 19 Op-Ed discussing how natural it is for young men in US to find violent solutions to psychosocial problems inherent in growing up; James D Peck suggests security measures for classroom
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''Laws Limit Colleges' Options When a Student Is Mentally Ill'' (front page, April 19):

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. -- In a speech at Rutgers University, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton today urged students to stand against cultural norms that she said marginalize or demean women, racial minorities, those of different sexual orientation or other social groups outside the mainstream.
docs.abstract: The senator speaks to students about the Don Imus controversy and praises the young women for objecting to his remarks.
docs.snippet: The senator speaks to students about the Don Imus controversy and praises the young women for objecting to his remarks.

docs.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
docs.abstract: In this lesson, the class will examine privacy laws as they relate to students who are suicidal or depressed. The class will then explore the role the government plays to protect these students and will consider how some legislation might actually endanger the public.
